## Stochastic Process

\begin{blueborder}{0.9\textwidth}{What is a stochastic process?}\begin{itemize}\item A procedure whose outcome is uncertain, or random.
\item When we carry out a realization of a stochastic process, we produce an outcome, e.g. a sampling \textit{event}.
\item The range of possible outcomes of a stochastic process is the \textit{sample space}.
\end{itemize}
\end{blueborder}

Probability theory studies stochastic processes

- It's nice when we can associate elements in the sample space with probabilities.






## Some Stochastic Process Examples

### stochastic processes

- Flipping a coin, drawing a hand of cards, lottery draw
- A random walk, Brownian motion

## Random Walks: 50 steps

```{r random_walk_50, echo = FALSE}
n = 50
par(mfrow = c(2, 3), mar = c(0, 0, 0, 0))
for (i in 1:6)
{
  dat = rwalk_1(n)
plot(
  y ~ x, data = dat, 
  type = "l", ann = FALSE, frame = TRUE, axes = FALSE, 
  lwd = 10, col = gray(0, 0.1),
  asp = 1)
points(
  y ~ x, data = dat, 
  type = "l", 
  lwd = 1, col = rgb(0, 0, 0.7, 1),
  asp = 1)
}
```
